text: today we're perfecting the mashed
potatoes and we have this great new
column we've been doing it for a few
months
it's called perfecting that and you
might think it's so simple
it can't be perfected or you might think
there's no such thing as perfection both
of which are sort of true but what we do
in this column is we explore something
in really in detail like what is
important about any given thing and in
mashed potatoes a lot of things it's the
kind of potato you use it's the dairy
that you put in it it's the flavorings
that you use it's the way that you cook
the potatoes it's what you match them
with so there are little details that
change it and it's not to say that one
way is better than the other but it's
good to know how they have an effect on
things and that's what we do in this
column we explore those things today I'm
making my mashed potatoes with Yukon
Gold 5 pounds of potatoes which is a lot
but you can make them ahead and reheat
them on a double boiler or keep them
warm on a double boiler I recommend
making them the morning of though it's
not something that you really want to
make the day before reheating mashed
potatoes from cold is not so fun but
keeping them warm for a couple of hours
ahead of time is great I like to have a
little bit of garlic in here and you get
a nice mild garlic flavor if you cook
the garlic in the water with the
potatoes some people like garlic like
roasted garlic which is also nice but
this is a really mild sweet garlic
flavor so add that directly to your
water and then add two tablespoons of
kosher salt you want to make sure that
the water is kind of salty because
that's going to infuse your potatoes
with flavor if the water isn't salty the
potatoes are going to be bland then what
you want to do is boil your potatoes
it'll take a little bit of time but this
is a big pot so give yourself at least a
half an hour but once it comes to a boil
it shouldn't take more than about 1215
minutes to cook so the milk mixture
you're going to want to heat
one-and-a-half cups of milk with one
stick of unsalted butter
[Applause]
make it a mess and for flavor some fresh
thyme about 2 sprigs well throw this a
little bit it should just melt and be
warm you want it warm when the potatoes
are ready and I'm realizing I'm doing it
now but my potatoes aren't cooked yet so
you really should wait let's just get it
ready and then I guess I can reheat it
effect with milk you're always going to
have to keep an eye on it because it can
easily over flow when it comes to a boil
so turn it off immediately and set it
aside if you need to reheat it when your
potatoes are done that's ok ok potatoes
are cooked
they're totally tender but you want to
do one more thing before you start
mixing with all the rest of the
ingredients you want to dry the potatoes
out so that they're as fluffy as
possible and if when they absorb the
liquids they don't get wet so you drain
the potatoes then you put them back into
the pot on the stove and cook them until
they start looking a little bit fluffy
on the outside just from the stirring
and a film will form on the bottom of
the pot I don't think you're going to be
able to see it in this pot because a hot
is kind of beat but when you're doing it
at home what you'll see is gets a little
bit sticky that starts from the potatoes
and it sort of forms a film on the
bottom of the pot and that's how you
know when your potatoes have dried out
enough to start adding your moisture and
which is in this case butter and milk
I've left my garlic cloves right in here
I'm just going to crush them right with
my potatoes that's where you're going to
get some really really excellent flavor
okay I think we're good here turn that
off now do you want your mashed potatoes
creamy if you want some creamy and like
super smooth use a ricer this is a ricer
I don't know if you have one it's great
for mashed potatoes but you can also
squeeze out excess liquid from stuff
like spinach and grated zucchini and
stuff just press it right through there
the finest mashed potatoes do you want
them a little bit more rustic use your
classic potato masher and it's totally
up to you there's no right or wrong I
think I'm going to have masher because I
kind of like them a little bit lumpy
remove them from the stove and then add
your warm milk butter mixture
if it did cool off a little bit if your
timing was as impeccable behind was you
can reheat it slightly you don't want
the pieces of time in there so just you
can pull them out I managed to pour all
my milk into the pot without getting the
time in which was excellent and then
just mash mash away all of these tips
are right in the magazine to was so
great I love the story can't go on
enough about it you're probably going to
want to season let me taste mm-hmm a
little bit of pepper but it's pretty
well seasoned with salt okay so here's
your sort of rustic mashed potato we
also have some other great variations of
the story russet potato with cream
cheese new potato with rosemary and
chicken stock instead of milk and
roasted sweet potato with nutmeg and
don't forget to finish with just one or
two or four packs of delicious butter
melt over the top and have everybody
swooning over your perfect match
potatoes
enjoy
